Kayako - ticket id 60220499 // Mike Kebede commented publicly: Dear Carlos,

We’ve escalated this case to the L2 team and raised the priority to High.

To assist their analysis, please provide the following:

	*
Speed test results before and after the GRO modification, including:

	*
Apple download (App Store, iOS/macOS updates) speed.

	*
Non-Apple download speed (e.g., Microsoft or large file tests).

	*
Relevant log data and diagnostics captured during both tests:

	*
Traffic Chart (showing interface throughput during download).

	*
Active Connections log (filtered for Apple CDN hosts such as *.apple.com, *.cdn-apple.com, appldnld.apple.com).

	*
Filter log (any entries showing Apple connections or drops).

	*
Debug log (if enabled, include the last ~1000 lines during the test).

	*
System Health data from the Dashboard: CPU, memory, and interface load levels during the download.

If possible, please also generate and attach the Support Information File (Status > System Health > Support > Download Support Information) — this includes network interface and driver details that are essential for the GRO analysis.

Thank you for your cooperation.

Best regards,
Mike Kebede
GFI - Kerio Control Support Team

Kayako - ticket id 60220499 // Jozef Kacala commented publicly: Hi Carlos,

As I am sure you know, I am not part of GFI technical support team. As such, I do not manage tickets created with technical support team.

in other ticket  60216786 I see Zubair exactly replied what I would recommend and that is to disable GRO https://support.keriocontrol.gfi.com/article/116160-configuring-gro-setting-for-maximum-bandwidth-in-kerio-control 

Apple devices do not "understand" GRO and that is the reason of slow traffic as basically it is caused by retransitions.

GRO is feature of the HW it self, specifically of physical ports where it is aggregating packets to larger which is then faster to be processed. So for normal (non apple) traffic it is actually increasing the speed. however Apple can not co-op. As we know many times Apple is behind of certain technology.

So this is not issue of the product or a bug, its question of settings and devices used in LAN.

thank you

Kayako - ticket id 60220499 // ADN Support commented privately: Dear GFI Support,

we are still experiencing the issue where Apple devices (iPhones, iPads, Macs) can only connect to Apple’s update and download servers at a very limited speed, around 300 KB/s.

It seems to be specifically related to how Kerio Control handles Apple’s CDN or update traffic.

Kayako - ticket id 60220499 // ATLAS commented publicly: Dear Support,

Thank you for your detailed follow-up, the updated screenshots, and confirmation that the dedicated Allow rule did not resolve the slow Apple-related download speeds through Kerio Control. Based on your configuration screenshots and file analysis, here are further insights and recommendations to help address the persistent issue:

Key Observations from Your Configuration:

 	* Your firewall rules correctly aim to exempt Apple domains via the "HTTPS exclusions" group and an Allow rule with NAT per host.
 	* Most relevant Apple CDN and update domains are included (appldnld.apple.com, *.cdn-apple.com, mesu.apple.com, swcdn.apple.com, etc.), but there is no broad *.apple.com entry. Recent changes to Apple’s CDN infrastructure may require even wider coverage.
 	* No filtering, bandwidth limiting, or explicit traffic inspection is visible for Apple traffic.
 	* The symptoms are consistent across LAN and Wi-Fi, with hardware resources not being saturated.

Recommendations and Next Steps:

	* Broaden the Allow/Exclusion Rules for Apple: 
Apple regularly adds new CDN endpoints and may route update/download traffic through domains not yet in your exclusion lists. The absence of a blanket *.apple.com entry in your Apple Updates or HTTPS exclusion groups means some traffic could still be routed through default firewall handling, resulting in inspection or fallback to slower servers.

Action: Add *.apple.com to both your "HTTPS exclusions" IP address group and your update-related URL groups. This will catch any unenumerated Apple subdomains and ensure all Apple CDN traffic bypasses filtering or inspection. Example entries to add: 

 	* *.apple.com
 	* *.cdn-apple.com

	* Verifying HTTP & HTTPS Handling: 
Ensure your exclusion rules apply to both HTTP and HTTPS traffic by using wildcard entries and confirming that there are no higher-priority rules that might inspect or restrict Apple domains. According to Apple’s documentation and GFI’s knowledge base, wide exceptions are needed due to Apple’s dynamic CDN behavior.

Reference articles: 

 	* Improving Speed performance [https://support.keriocontrol.gfi.com/article/116215] 
 	* Apple devices to get through the authentication page [https://support.keriocontrol.gfi.com/article/120298] 

 	* Re-Test After Expanding Exclusions: 
After fully whitelisting *.apple.com and *.cdn-apple.com, retest downloads from the App Store, software update, and iOS update functions using a device on both LAN and Wi-Fi. This will ensure all possible Apple update endpoints are allowed as Apple frequently rotates subdomains and CDN paths for different services/devices. 
 	* AppManager Service Check (if not already Disabled): 
If the GFI AppManager (GFI Agent) service is active on your Kerio Control 9.5.x server, disable it as described in the article Troubleshooting Kerio Control 9.5.0 Performance Degradation [https://support.keriocontrol.gfi.com/article/126211]. In some cases, even when general performance seems unaffected, this service can cause application-specific throughput issues. 

Additional Notes:

 	* Apple’s CDN coverage evolves constantly. Periodically review and update your exclusion groups to cover new subdomains or endpoints as needed.
 	* If possible, confirm there are no additional security or parental control applications between Kerio Control and your endpoint devices that could also be inspecting Apple traffic.
 	* For long-term stability, consider scripting a regular review of Apple's published IP ranges for automated updates to your exclusion group if feasible in your environment.

Expanding your exclusion rules as described above resolves Apple download speed issues in most environments where general throughput is otherwise unaffected by Kerio Control. Should the issue persist after applying these steps, continue to check for further CDN changes by Apple or investigate any network pathing changes specific to your ISP and their upstream Apple CDN peering.

Sincerely,
Atlas
GFI - Kerio Control Support Team.

Kayako - ticket id 60220499 // ATLAS commented publicly: Dear Support,

Thank you for describing the troubleshooting already performed and providing the screenshot for context regarding slow Apple-related downloads through Kerio Control.

Summary of Findings

Your diagnostic steps and screenshot show:

 	* The affected traffic is isolated to Apple update and download endpoints; Microsoft and general downloads are unaffected.
 	* Features that commonly impact throughput (Content Filter, IPS, Antivirus, Geo-blocking, Shield Matrix, Bandwidth Management/QoS) are disabled or not in use.
 	* No active filtering or throttling seems present in the Apple-related URL groups based on your screenshot.
 	* Traffic persists as slow (~300 KB/s) on both LAN and Wi-Fi, and system resources appear sufficient.

Possible Causes and Solutions

Kerio Control is designed as a UTM firewall, and some features—even when disabled—can interact with specific CDN behaviors (like those used by Apple). Below are steps and references that may help further isolate or mitigate the issue:

 	* Hardware and Network Considerations
Although your i7 hardware is not overloaded, ensure that all Apple update streams are genuinely passing uninspected through the firewall. Sometimes hidden deep-packet inspection or transparent proxy mechanisms can cause this type of unique slowdown for specific CDNs. 
Full Speed Performance Article [https://support.keriocontrol.gfi.com/article/116215] 
 	* Apple CDN Endpoint Coverage
The list shown in your screenshot covers major Apple update endpoints (appldnld.apple.com, *.cdn.apple.com, mesu.apple.com, sw*.apple.com, updates.cdn-apple.com). However, Apple frequently updates and expands its CDN domains.
Recommendation: Occasionally review and update these lists to ensure new endpoints are not missed—which could cause traffic to take slower fallback routes. 
 	* VM/Hypervisor Settings (if applicable)
If Kerio Control is virtualized, ensure that CPU and memory resources are allocated sufficiently and with high priority, as covered in the Improving Speed performance [https://support.keriocontrol.gfi.com/article/116215] article. 
 	* Apple Device Connectivity Exception Rules
While your current setup does not use web authentication, Apple devices can sometimes perform background connectivity checks to other Apple endpoints. If any authentication or inspection was enforced for *.apple.com traffic, it could disrupt these background checks or slow downloads.
Reference: Apple devices to get through the authentication page [https://support.keriocontrol.gfi.com/article/120298] 
 	* Test with Additional Known Apple CDN URLs
Consider temporarily adding a rule to explicitly allow all traffic to *.apple.com and *.cdn-apple.com without inspection or filtering (even if no rules currently restrict this), to rule out hidden filtering effects. 
 	* Application Layer Features and Version-Specific Issues
The Troubleshooting Kerio Control 9.5.0 Performance Degradation [https://support.keriocontrol.gfi.com/article/126211] article addresses a known issue with Kerio Control 9.5.0 involving the GFI AppManager service causing severe throughput degradation for some traffic types. While this issue usually manifests globally, if AppManager (labeled “GFI Agent”) is enabled, consider disabling it and observing any impact—even though you report general performance is otherwise unaffected. 

Further Notes

 	* Your current configuration and diagnostic approach align with our best practices for isolating throughput issues.
 	* This issue appears to be unique to how Apple’s CDN interacts with some firewall engines and may require continuous adjustment of whitelist domains as Apple evolves their infrastructure.
 	* Test download speed both via browser and direct Apple device update (iPhone/iPad), as Apple may use different servers depending on the method.

Reference Articles:

 	* Improving Speed performance [https://support.keriocontrol.gfi.com/article/116215]
 	* Apple devices to get through the authentication page [https://support.keriocontrol.gfi.com/article/120298]
 	* Troubleshooting Kerio Control 9.5.0 Performance Degradation [https://support.keriocontrol.gfi.com/article/126211]

If the above checks do not resolve the issue and all other bandwidth management, filtering, and AV/QoS components are verified as off or bypassed, continuing to expand the explicit “Allow” rules for Apple endpoints may further help. Apple frequently adds or changes CDN URLs, and traffic could be slow if hitting fallback or non-primary nodes due to incomplete access lists.

If you have further questions or observe new behaviors, please let us know.

Sincerely,
Atlas
GFI - Kerio Control Support Team.

Kayako - ticket id 60220499 // ADN Support commented privately: Dear GFI Support,
one of our partners is experiencing an issue with Kerio Control 9.5p3, the problem started around version 9.4.

Issue description:

- Microsoft downloads (e.g. Windows Updates) run at full speed — no issues there.
- Apple downloads (App Store, iOS updates, downloads on iPhones/iPads, etc.) are extremely slow, around 300 KB/s.
- The internet connection is a 1 Gbit/s symmetrical fiber line, and the slowdown only affects Apple-related downloads.

Troubleshooting already done:

- Content filtering: disabled
- Intrusion Prevention (IPS): disabled
- Shield Matrix: disabled
- Antivirus and Geo-Blocking: disabled
- Bandwidth Management (QoS): not in use
- Same result over both LAN and Wi-Fi
- System load stays below 50% (Firewall runs on an i7 with 6 cores and 8 GB RAM)

The issue persists regardless of these settings.

Are you aware of similar cases, or is there a known workaround or configuration change to improve Apple download speeds?

Thanks in advance for your help
